attributes.alt: Book cover for Hey, Wall: A Story of Art and Community written by Susan Verde and illustrated by John Parra. The illustration shows people painting images on a wall.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
What do we learn about where the  boy lives?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Ask and answer questions to seek help or information.
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs; Understand a growing number of social studies words.
Identify own body within surroundings and respect others’ personal space.
Show understanding of the importance of taking care of  the planet.
Help children identify ways that people can care for their neighborhoods.
Help children use frequently occurring nouns and verbs in their responses.
What is it like where we live?
What buildings do you see in  that book?
What can you pretend to do with your neighbors?
How can you sort those toys?
What is your favorite place in your neighborhood? What do you do there?
What materials can you use to make a tree?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word
Can you use blocks to build a wall? What other materials can you use to make a wall?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Ask and answer questions to seek help or information.
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs; Understand a growing number of social studies words.
Identify own body within surroundings and respects others’ personal space.
Help children use their flexible thinking skills to look at the same picture in different ways.
Help children use frequently occurring nouns and verbs in their responses.
What is it like where we live?
Can you name a place that looks like our town?
Pretend you just got a great idea.
Can you draw three people who live near you?
Write about something beautiful in your neighborhood.
Can you draw and color a place in your neighborhood?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word
What materials can you use  to build a wall like the one in  the story?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Hey, Wall: A Story of Art and Community written by Susan Verde and illustrated by John Parra. The illustration shows people painting images on a wall.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
What does the boy think about the wall in the beginning of the story?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Ask and answer questions to seek help or information.
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs; Understand a growing number of social studies words.
Identify own body within surroundings and respect others’ personal space.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Have children act out different scenes from
Encourage children to dance to different musical styles.
What is it like where we live?
How are the buildings in those books the same? Different?
Can you show me two things you do at home?
Can you compare the size of two buildings? Which is bigger?
Can you write about why the boy wants to change the wall?
Draw a store from your town. What colors will you use to  color it?
What letter makes the sound  you hear at the beginning of the word
The neighbors used ladders to paint the wall. Can you build a ladder? What materials will  you use?

Book cover for Hey, Wall: A Story of Art and Community written by Susan Verde and illustrated by John Parra. The illustration shows people painting images on a wall.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background and introduce vocabulary words
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question,
What is it like where we live?
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs; Understand a growing number of social studies words.
Use language for different purposes and match language to social contexts.
Identify own body within surroundings and respect others’ personal space.
Explore geography tools and resources, such as maps, signs, and street addresses.
React to a variety of musical styles through movement and play.
Help children identify where people are in their neighborhood.
Help children practice subject-verb agreement by asking questions with singular and plural subjects.
What is it like where we live?
What do you think the boy likes the most about his neighborhood?
Pretend you are reading a book in a library.
Draw three things that have different sizes that you would give to a friend.
Write about a place you would like to visit.
Can you make a map of  our school?
Can you tell me the sound you hear at the beginning of the  word
Can you build a fire station? What will your fire station have?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Hey, Wall: A Story of Art and Community written by Susan Verde and illustrated by John Parra. The illustration shows people painting images on a wall.

elements.text: Life Science; Earth and Space Science
Use Circle Time to have children act out scenes from
What is life like in a big city?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs; Understand a growing number of social studies words.
Investigate, describe, and talk about materials from the earth and how they are used; Show understanding of the importance of taking care of the planet.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
What is your favorite place to visit in your neighborhood?
Save children’s writing to display next week.
What is it like where we live?
If you wrote a book about your neighborhood, what would you put in it?
Can you pretend to be watering a tree that you just planted?
Draw the biggest tree that grows in your neighborhood.
Create a story about a neighborhood.
Can you imagine a beautiful park in a town? What is in the park? Can you draw the park?
What letter do you hear at the beginning of the word
Build a park. Why did you use those materials to make your park? Could you use other materials?
